summary: Step 1: Filters low quality, low complexity, duplicate, and host reads

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: maximum number of bytes to read from a file into each partition of reads. Setting this higher will result in fewer partitions. Note that this will not be equal to the size of the partition in memory. Defaults to 0, which uses the default split size (determined by the Hadoop input format, typically the size of one HDFS block).
arguments.name: --bam-partition-size

arguments.summary: Spark properties to set on the Spark context in the format <property>=<value>
arguments.name: --conf

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM splitting index (SBI) when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-splitting-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: Base quality to assign low-complexity bases
arguments.name: --dust-mask-quality

arguments.summary: DUST algorithm score threshold
arguments.name: --dust-t
arguments.fulltext: Controls the stringency of low-complexity filtering.

arguments.summary: DUST algorithm window size
arguments.name: --dust-window

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: The BWA image file of the host reference. This must be distributed to local disk on each node.
arguments.name: --filter-bwa-image
arguments.fulltext: This file should be generated using BwaMemIndexImageCreator.

arguments.summary: Minimum seed length for the host BWA alignment.
arguments.name: --filter-bwa-seed-length
arguments.fulltext:
Controls the sensitivity of BWA alignment to the host reference. Shorter seed lengths will enhance detection of
 host reads during the subtraction phase but will also increase run time.

arguments.summary: Filter duplicate reads
arguments.name: --filter-duplicates
arguments.fulltext:
If true, then for any two reads with identical sequences (or identical to the other's reverse complement), one
 will be filtered.

arguments.summary: Log counts of filtered reads to this file
arguments.name: --filter-metrics
arguments.fulltext:
If specified, records the number of reads remaining after each of the following steps:
  • Pre-aligned host read filtering
  • Low-quality and low-complexity sequence filtering
  • Host read subtraction
  • Read deduplication

It also provides the following:

  • Number of low-quality and low-complexity reads removed
  • Number of host reads removed
  • Number of duplicate reads removed
  • Final number of reads
  • Final number of paired reads
  • Final number of unpaired reads

Note that using this option may substantially increase runtime.

arguments.summary: Estimated reads per partition after quality, kmer, and BWA filtering
arguments.name: --filter-reads-per-partition
arguments.fulltext:
This is a parameter for fine-tuning memory performance. Lower values may result in less memory usage but possibly
 at the expense of greater computation time.

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: Host kmer count threshold.
arguments.name: --host-kmer-thresh
arguments.fulltext:
Controls the stringency of read filtering based on host k-mer matching. Reads with at least this many matching
 k-mers in the host reference will be filtered.

arguments.summary: Host alignment identity score threshold, in bp
arguments.name: --host-min-identity
arguments.fulltext:
Controls the stringency of read filtering based on alignment to the host reference. The identity score is defined
 as the number of matching bases less the number of deletions in the alignment.

arguments.summary: Host-aligned BAM contigs to ignore
arguments.name: --ignore-alignment-contigs
arguments.fulltext:
If using --is-host-aligned, ignores alignments to these contigs (can be specified multiple times). This
 can be useful if the alignment is to a reference containing a microbe, such as chrEBV in hg38.

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: Set if the input BAM is aligned to the host
arguments.name: --is-host-aligned
arguments.fulltext: PathSeq will rapidly filter the reads if they are aligned to a host reference, thus reducing run time.

arguments.summary: Path to host k-mer file generated with PathSeqBuildKmers. K-mer filtering is skipped if this is not specified.
arguments.name: --kmer-file

arguments.summary: Maximum number of mismatches for adapter trimming
arguments.name: --max-adapter-mismatches

arguments.summary: Max allowable number of masked bases per read
arguments.name: --max-masked-bases
arguments.fulltext:
This is the threshold for filtering reads based on the number of 'N' values present in the sequence. Note that the low-complexity DUST filter and quality filter mask using 'N' bases. Therefore, this parameter is the threshold for the sum of:
  • The number of N's in the original input read
  • The number of low-quality base calls
  • The number of low-complexity bases

arguments.summary: Minimum length of adapter sequence to trim
arguments.name: --min-adapter-length
arguments.fulltext: Adapter trimming will require a match of at least this length to a known adapter.

arguments.summary: Bases below this call quality will be masked with 'N'
arguments.name: --min-base-quality

arguments.summary: Minimum length of reads after quality trimming
arguments.name: --min-clipped-read-length
arguments.fulltext:
Reads are trimmed based on base call quality and low-complexity content. Decreasing the value will enhance pathogen
 detection (higher sensitivity) but also result in undesired false positives and ambiguous microbe alignments
 (lower specificity).

arguments.summary: For tools that shuffle data or write an output, sets the number of reducers. Defaults to 0, which gives one partition per 10MB of input.
arguments.name: --num-reducers

arguments.summary: when writing a bam, in single sharded mode this directory to write the temporary intermediate output shards, if not specified .parts/ will be used
arguments.name: --output-shard-tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Output BAM containing only paired reads
arguments.name: --paired-output

arguments.summary: Name of the program running
arguments.name: --program-name

arguments.summary: Quality score trimmer threshold
arguments.name: --quality-threshold
arguments.fulltext: Controls the stingency of base call quality-based read trimming. Higher values result in more trimming.

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: For tools that write an output, write the output in multiple pieces (shards)
arguments.name: --sharded-output

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: Skip pre-BWA repartition. Set to true for inputs with a high proportion of microbial reads that are not host coordinate-sorted.
arguments.name: --skip-pre-bwa-repartition
arguments.fulltext:
Advanced optimization option that should be used only in the case of inputs with a high proportion of microbial reads that are not host-aligned/coordinate-sorted.

In the filter tool, the input reads are initially divided up into smaller partitions (default size is usually the size of one HDFS block, or ~64MB) that Spark works on in parallel. In samples with a low proportion of microbial reads (e.g. < 1%), the steps leading up to the host BWA alignment will whittle these partitions down to a small fraction of their original size. At that point, the distribution of reads across the partitions may be unbalanced.

For example, say the input is 256MB and Spark splits this into 4 even partitions. It is possible that, after running through the quality filters and host kmer search, there are 5% remaining in partition #1, 8% in partition #2, 2% in partition #3, and 20% in partition #4. Thus there is an imbalance of work across the partitions. To correct this, a "reparitioning" is invoked that distributes the reads evenly. Note this is especially important for host-aligned, coordinate-sorted inputs, in which unmapped reads would be concentrated in the last partitions.

If, however, the proportion of microbial reads is higher, say 30%, then the partitions are generally more balanced (except for in the aforementioned coordinate-sorted case). In this case, the time spent doing the repartitioning is usually greater than the time saved by rebalancing, and this option should be invoked.

arguments.summary: Skip low-quality and low-complexity read filtering
arguments.name: --skip-quality-filters

arguments.summary: URL of the Spark Master to submit jobs to when using the Spark pipeline runner.
arguments.name: --spark-master

arguments.summary: Spark verbosity. Overrides --verbosity for Spark-generated logs only. Possible values: {ALL, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL, OFF, TRACE}
arguments.name: --spark-verbosity

arguments.summary: Granularity to use when writing a splitting index, one entry will be put into the index every n reads where n is this granularity value. Smaller granularity results in a larger index with more available split points.
arguments.name: --splitting-index-granularity

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Output BAM containing only unpaired reads
arguments.name: --unpaired-output

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use NIO or the Hadoop filesystem (default) for reading files. (Note that the Hadoop filesystem is always used for writing files.)
arguments.name: --use-nio

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
Filters low complexity, low quality, duplicate, and host reads. First step in the PathSeq pipeline.

See PathSeqPipelineSpark for an overview of the PathSeq pipeline.

Methods

The tool works by filtering out reads in a series of stages:

  1. Remove secondary and supplementary alignments
  2. If the input reads are aligned to a host reference, remove mapped reads with sufficient alignment identity
  3. Trim adapter sequences
  4. Mask sequences with excessive A/T or G/C content
  5. Mask repetitive sequences (see Liebert et al. 2006)
  6. Hard clip read ends using base qualities
  7. Remove reads that are too short or were trimmed excessively
  8. Mask low-quality bases
  9. Remove reads with too many masked bases
  10. Remove reads containing one or more host k-mers
  11. Remove reads with sufficient alignment identity to the host reference
  12. Remove exact duplicate reads

Input

  • BAM containing input reads (either unaligned or aligned to a host reference)
  • *Host k-mer file generated using PathSeqBuildKmers
  • *Host BWA-MEM index image generated using BwaMemIndexImageCreator

*A standard host reference is available in the GATK Resource Bundle.

Output

  • BAM containing high quality, non-host paired reads (paired-end reads with both mates)
  • BAM containing high quality, non-host unpaired reads (single-end reads and/or paired-end reads without mates)

Usage example

This tool can be run without explicitly specifying Spark options. That is to say, the given example command without Spark options will run locally. See Tutorial#10060 for an example of how to set up and run a Spark tool on a cloud Spark cluster.

Local mode:

 gatk PathSeqFilterSpark  \
   --input input_reads.bam \
   --paired-output output_reads_paired.bam \
   --unpaired-output output_reads_unpaired.bam \
   --min-clipped-read-length 60 \
   --kmer-file host_kmers.bfi \
   --filter-bwa-image host_reference.img \
   --filter-metrics metrics.txt \
   --bam-partition-size 4000000

Spark cluster on Google Cloud DataProc with 4 16-core / 100GB memory worker nodes:

 gatk PathSeqFilterSpark  \
   --input gs://my-gcs-bucket/input_reads.bam \
   --paired-output gs://my-gcs-bucket/output_reads_paired.bam \
   --unpaired-output gs://my-gcs-bucket/output_reads_unpaired.bam \
   --min-clipped-read-length 60 \
   --kmer-file hdfs://my-cluster-m:8020//references/host_kmers.bfi \
   --filter-bwa-image /references/host_reference.img \
   --filter-metrics gs://my-gcs-bucket/metrics.txt \
   --bam-partition-size 4000000 \
   -- \
   --sparkRunner GCS \
   --cluster my_cluster \
   --driver-memory 8G \
   --executor-memory 32G \
   --num-executors 4 \
   --executor-cores 15 \
   --conf spark.executor.memoryOverhead=32000

Note that the host BWA image must be copied to the same path on every worker node. The host k-mer file may also be copied to a single path on every worker node or to HDFS.

Notes

The input BAM may be unaligned (a uBAM) or aligned to a host reference (e.g. hg38). If it is aligned then --is-host-aligned should be enabled. This will substantially increase performance, as host reads can then be immediately subtracted prior to quality filtering and host alignment.

References

  1. Liebert, M. A. et al. (2006). A Fast and Symmetric DUST Implementation to Mask Low-Complexity DNA Sequences. J. Comput. Biol., 13, 1028-1040.
name: PathSeqFilterSpark
